newsitem.title: GERMANY: German car import sales rise 5.5 percent in 1996.
newsitem.headline: German car import sales rise 5.5 percent in 1996.

text.p: Sales of imported cars in Germany rose 5.5 percent to about 3.50 million vehicles in 1996, accounting for one-third of all vehicle sales, the German Association of Automobile Importers (VDIK) said on Tuesday.
VDIK President Volker Lange said the gains came in former West Germany, where sales rose 8.1 percent over 1995 levels, because sales in former East Germany fell by 6.4 percent.
Lange said he expected 2.4 percent growth in sales for 1997 despite ongoing difficult industry conditions.
Despite the sales increase among imported passenger vehicles, the VDIK said import truck sales slipped 3.8 percent to 250,521 vehicles for a 35 percent market share.
In former West Germany, the VDIK said the market share for imported cars was 29.6 percent in 1996 but was 47.2 percent in east Germany, where almost every second car was an import.
In the German market, the VDIK said Japan was the top seller with an 11.7 percent market share, followed by France at nine percent and Italy third at 4.9 percent.
